documents.title: Facial Nerve (CN VII) Complete Anatomy
documents.content:
The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is a mixed nerve containing motor, sensory, and parasympathetic fibers. It exits the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle, enters the internal acoustic meatus, and travels through the facial canal in the temporal bone.

Key branches and their functions:
1. Greater petrosal nerve - parasympathetic to lacrimal gland (lacrimation)
2. Nerve to stapedius - dampens loud sounds (hyperacusis if damaged)
3. Chorda tympani - taste to anterior 2/3 tongue, parasympathetic to submandibular/sublingual glands
4. Terminal motor branches - muscles of facial expression

The nerve exits the skull through the stylomastoid foramen. Lesions at different levels produce distinct clinical findings:
- At stylomastoid foramen: Loss of motor function only (facial paralysis)
- Above chorda tympani: + loss of taste and salivation
- At geniculate ganglion: + loss of lacrimation (dry eye)
- At internal acoustic meatus: + hearing loss

Bell's palsy is idiopathic facial nerve paralysis, most common cause of unilateral facial weakness.

documents.title: Pulmonary Surfactant Biochemistry and Function
documents.content:
Pulmonary surfactant is a complex mixture of lipids (90%) and proteins (10%) produced by type II alveolar pneumocytes (type II cells).

Composition:
- Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) - 50%, main surface-active component
- Phosphatidylglycerol - 8-15%
- Surfactant proteins A, B, C, D (SP-A, SP-B, SP-C, SP-D)

Functions:
1. Reduces alveolar surface tension - prevents atelectasis (collapse)
2. Maintains alveolar stability at different volumes (Laplace's law)
3. Facilitates gas exchange
4. Innate immune defense (SP-A and SP-D are collectins)

Clinical significance:
- Neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS): Surfactant deficiency in premature infants (<35 weeks)
- Treatment: Exogenous surfactant replacement (beractant, poractant)
- Lecithin/Sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio >2.0 indicates lung maturity
- Phosphatidylglycerol presence confirms maturity

documents.title: Pulmonary Embolism Diagnosis and Management
documents.content:
Pulmonary embolism (PE) occurs when a blood clot, usually from deep vein thrombosis (DVT), lodges in the pulmonary arteries.

Risk Factors (Virchow's Triad):
- Stasis: Immobility, long flights, paralysis
- Endothelial injury: Surgery, trauma, catheters
- Hypercoagulability: Cancer, Factor V Leiden, pregnancy, OCPs

Clinical Presentation:
- Dyspnea (most common), pleuritic chest pain, tachypnea, tachycardia
- Massive PE: Hypotension, syncope, sudden death
- Signs: Low SpO2, elevated JVP, loud P2

Diagnosis:
1. D-dimer: High sensitivity, low specificity - use to RULE OUT in low-probability
2. CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA): GOLD STANDARD, shows filling defects
3. V/Q scan: Alternative when CTPA contraindicated (renal failure, contrast allergy)
4. Echocardiography: RV strain, McConnell's sign
5. Lower extremity Doppler: Identify DVT source

Wells Score for PE probability: Points for clinical signs, heart rate, immobilization, previous VTE, hemoptysis, malignancy

Treatment:
- Anticoagulation: Heparin bridge to warfarin, or DOACs (rivaroxaban, apixaban)
- Massive PE with hemodynamic instability: Thrombolytics (alteplase), embolectomy
- IVC filter: When anticoagulation contraindicated

documents.title: Sickle Cell Disease Genetics and Pathophysiology
documents.content:
Sickle cell disease (SCD) is an autosomal recessive hemoglobinopathy caused by a point mutation in the beta-globin gene (HBB) on chromosome 11.

Genetics:
- Mutation: GAG → GTG at codon 6
- Amino acid change: Glutamic acid → Valine (Glu6Val or E6V)
- Results in abnormal hemoglobin S (HbS)
- Sickle cell trait (HbAS): One copy, carrier state, generally asymptomatic
- Sickle cell disease (HbSS): Homozygous, symptomatic disease

Pathophysiology:
- HbS polymerizes under low oxygen tension
- Red blood cells become rigid and sickle-shaped
- Sickling leads to: Hemolysis, vaso-occlusion, tissue ischemia

Clinical Manifestations:
1. Vaso-occlusive crisis: Severe pain in bones, chest, abdomen
2. Acute chest syndrome: Fever, chest pain, pulmonary infiltrate - leading cause of death
3. Splenic sequestration: Rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia
4. Aplastic crisis: Often triggered by Parvovirus B19
5. Stroke: Children at highest risk
6. Functional asplenia: Increased infection risk (encapsulated organisms)

Treatment:
- Hydroxyurea: Increases HbF, reduces crises
- Blood transfusions: For acute complications
- Bone marrow transplant: Curative but limited availability
- Prophylactic penicillin: Until age 5 (pneumococcal prevention)

documents.title: Vitamin D Metabolism and Immune Function
documents.content:
Vitamin D is a fat-soluble secosteroid hormone essential for calcium homeostasis and immune regulation.

Metabolism:
1. Skin synthesis: 7-dehydrocholesterol → Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) via UVB
2. Liver: 25-hydroxylation → 25(OH)D (calcidiol) - measured to assess status
3. Kidney: 1α-hydroxylation → 1,25(OH)2D (calcitriol) - active form

Immune Functions:
- Enhances innate immunity: Macrophage antimicrobial peptides (cathelicidin, defensins)
- Modulates adaptive immunity: Reduces Th1/Th17 responses, promotes Treg cells
- Vitamin D receptors (VDR) present on most immune cells

Clinical Evidence for Respiratory Infections:
- Meta-analyses show vitamin D supplementation reduces respiratory tract infections
- Benefit greatest in those with baseline deficiency (<25 nmol/L)
- Daily or weekly dosing more effective than bolus doses
- Evidence for COVID-19 prevention: Mixed/inconclusive
- Evidence for influenza prevention: Modest benefit, especially in deficient individuals

Deficiency:
- Levels: Deficient <20 ng/mL, Insufficient 20-30 ng/mL, Sufficient >30 ng/mL
- Risk factors: Limited sun exposure, dark skin, obesity, malabsorption
- Consequences: Rickets (children), osteomalacia (adults), increased infection susceptibility

documents.title: Ulcerative Colitis Pathology and Cancer Risk
documents.content:
Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting the colon and rectum with continuous mucosal inflammation.

Pathology:
- Inflammation limited to mucosa and submucosa
- Always involves rectum, extends proximally in continuous pattern
- Histology: Crypt abscesses, goblet cell depletion, pseudopolyps
- No granulomas (distinguishes from Crohn's disease)

Clinical Features:
- Bloody diarrhea (hallmark)
- Tenesmus, urgency, cramping abdominal pain
- Extraintestinal: Pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum, uveitis, arthritis, PSC

Classification by Extent:
- Proctitis: Rectum only
- Left-sided colitis: Up to splenic flexure
- Pancolitis: Entire colon

Colorectal Cancer Risk:
- Significantly elevated compared to general population
- Risk factors: Duration >8-10 years, extent of disease (pancolitis highest), severity
- Cumulative risk: ~2% at 10 years, ~8% at 20 years, ~18% at 30 years
- Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) further increases risk
- Surveillance colonoscopy recommended starting 8 years after diagnosis
- Dysplasia on biopsy: Consider colectomy

Treatment:
- 5-ASA compounds (mesalamine): First-line for mild-moderate
- Corticosteroids: Acute flares
- Immunomodulators: Azathioprine, 6-MP for steroid-sparing
- Biologics: Anti-TNF (infliximab), anti-integrins (vedolizumab)
- Surgery: Proctocolectomy with IPAA is curative

documents.title: Organophosphate Poisoning Recognition and Treatment
documents.content:
Organophosphates (OPs) are cholinesterase inhibitors found in pesticides (malathion, parathion) and nerve agents (sarin, VX).

Mechanism:
- Irreversibly inhibit acetylcholinesterase (AChE)
- Cause accumulation of acetylcholine at synapses
- Affects muscarinic, nicotinic, and CNS receptors

Clinical Presentation (Cholinergic Toxidrome):
SLUDGE/DUMBBELSS:
- Salivation, Lacrimation, Urination, Defecation, GI distress, Emesis
- Diarrhea, Urination, Miosis, Bronchospasm/Bradycardia, Emesis, Lacrimation, Salivation, Sweating

Nicotinic effects: Muscle fasciculations, weakness, paralysis, tachycardia
CNS effects: Anxiety, seizures, coma

Key Signs:
- MIOSIS (pinpoint pupils) - classic finding
- Excessive secretions (bronchorrhea, salivation)
- Muscle weakness progressing to respiratory failure
- Garlic/petroleum odor

Treatment:
1. Decontamination: Remove clothing, wash skin, gastric lavage if ingested
2. Atropine: Muscarinic antagonist - give until secretions dry
   - Large doses often needed (may require hundreds of mg)
   - Endpoint: Drying of secretions, NOT pupil size
3. Pralidoxime (2-PAM): Reactivates AChE before "aging" (permanent binding)
   - Must give within 24-48 hours
   - Addresses nicotinic symptoms (muscle weakness)
4. Benzodiazepines: For seizures
5. Supportive: Intubation if respiratory failure

documents.title: Oral Candidiasis Diagnosis and Management
documents.content:
Oral candidiasis (thrush) is a fungal infection of the oral mucosa caused by Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans.

Risk Factors:
- Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, transplant
- Diabetes mellitus (poorly controlled)
- Antibiotics (disrupt normal flora)
- Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) - common cause in asthmatics
- Dentures, dry mouth (xerostomia)
- Extremes of age (neonates, elderly)

Clinical Forms:
1. Pseudomembranous (thrush): White, curd-like plaques that can be scraped off, revealing erythematous base
2. Erythematous: Red, atrophic patches, often on palate
3. Angular cheilitis: Erythema and fissuring at mouth corners

Diagnosis:
- Usually clinical based on appearance
- KOH preparation: Pseudohyphae and budding yeast
- Culture: Confirms species, assess antifungal susceptibility

Treatment:
Mild cases (immunocompetent):
- Nystatin suspension: Swish and swallow, 4-5 times daily × 7-14 days
- Clotrimazole troches: Dissolve in mouth 5 times daily

Moderate-severe or immunocompromised:
- Fluconazole 100-200 mg daily × 7-14 days (first-line systemic)
- Itraconazole solution: Alternative

Prevention in ICS users:
- Rinse mouth with water after each use
- Use spacer device with MDI
- Consider lower ICS dose if recurrent

Refractory cases: Consider HIV testing, evaluate for esophageal involvement

documents.title: Diabetes Mellitus Classification and Diagnosis
documents.content:
Diabetes mellitus is a group of metabolic diseases characterized by hyperglycemia resulting from defects in insulin secretion, insulin action, or both.

Classification:
1. Type 1 DM (5-10%): Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells
   - Absolute insulin deficiency
   - Markers: Anti-GAD, anti-islet cell, anti-insulin antibodies
   - Prone to DKA

2. Type 2 DM (90-95%): Insulin resistance + relative insulin deficiency
   - Associated with obesity, metabolic syndrome
   - Often asymptomatic initially
   - Prone to HHS (hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state)

3. Gestational DM: Onset during pregnancy
4. Other: MODY, drug-induced, pancreatitis

Diagnostic Criteria (any one):
- Fasting plasma glucose ≥126 mg/dL (≥7.0 mmol/L)
- 2-hour plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL during OGTT
- HbA1c ≥6.5%
- Random glucose ≥200 mg/dL with classic symptoms

Classic Symptoms (3 P's):
- Polyuria, Polydipsia, Polyphagia
- Weight loss (especially Type 1)
- Fatigue, blurred vision

Complications:
Microvascular:
- Retinopathy: Leading cause of blindness in working-age adults
- Nephropathy: Leading cause of ESRD
- Neuropathy: Peripheral (stocking-glove), autonomic

Macrovascular:
- Coronary artery disease
- Cerebrovascular disease (stroke)
- Peripheral arterial disease

documents.title: Acute Coronary Syndrome Management
documents.content:
Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) encompasses unstable angina, NSTEMI, and STEMI, representing a spectrum of myocardial ischemia.

Classification:
1. Unstable Angina: Ischemic symptoms at rest, no troponin elevation
2. NSTEMI: Elevated troponins without ST elevation on ECG
3. STEMI: ST elevation ≥1mm in 2 contiguous leads (or new LBBB)

Initial Management (MONA-B):
- Morphine: Pain relief (use with caution)
- Oxygen: If SpO2 <90%
- Nitrates: Sublingual then IV (contraindicated in RV infarct, hypotension)
- Aspirin: 325 mg chewed immediately
- Beta-blocker: Reduce oxygen demand (unless contraindicated)

Antiplatelet/Anticoagulation:
- Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT): Aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor (clopidogrel, ticagrelor, prasugrel)
- Anticoagulation: Heparin (UFH or enoxaparin)

STEMI-Specific:
- Primary PCI: Preferred if door-to-balloon time <90 minutes
- Fibrinolytics: If PCI not available within 120 minutes
  - tPA (alteplase), tenecteplase, streptokinase
  - Contraindications: Recent surgery, stroke, bleeding

Post-ACS Management:
- DAPT: 12 months post-stent
- High-intensity statin
- ACE inhibitor (especially if EF reduced or anterior MI)
- Beta-blocker
- Cardiac rehabilitation

documents.title: Pneumonia Classification and Empiric Treatment
documents.content:
Pneumonia is infection of the lung parenchyma causing consolidation and impaired gas exchange.

Classification:
1. Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP): Acquired outside hospital setting
2. Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP): ≥48 hours after admission
3. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): ≥48 hours after intubation
4. Aspiration Pneumonia: From oropharyngeal contents

Common Pathogens:
CAP:
- Streptococcus pneumoniae: Most common typical pathogen
- Haemophilus influenzae
- Moraxella catarrhalis
- Atypical: Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydophila pneumoniae, Legionella

HAP/VAP: Pseudomonas, MRSA, Klebsiella, Acinetobacter

Treatment Guidelines:
Outpatient CAP (no comorbidities):
- Amoxicillin OR Doxycycline OR Macrolide (azithromycin)

Outpatient CAP (with comorbidities):
- Respiratory fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin) OR
- Beta-lactam + Macrolide

Inpatient CAP (non-ICU):
- Respiratory fluoroquinolone OR
- Beta-lactam (ceftriaxone, ampicillin-sulbactam) + Macrolide

Inpatient CAP (ICU):
- Beta-lactam + Macrolide OR Respiratory fluoroquinolone
- Add vancomycin if MRSA suspected

HAP/VAP:
- Anti-pseudomonal coverage + Anti-MRSA coverage

Severity Assessment - CURB-65:
- Confusion, Uremia (BUN >19), Respiratory rate ≥30, BP <90/60, Age ≥65
- Score 0-1: Outpatient; 2: Consider admission; ≥3: Hospital/ICU

documents.title: Asthma Stepwise Management
documents.content:
Asthma is a chronic inflammatory airway disease characterized by reversible airflow obstruction, bronchial hyperresponsiveness, and airway inflammation.

Pathophysiology:
- Th2-mediated inflammation with eosinophils, mast cells
- Airway smooth muscle hyperreactivity
- Mucus hypersecretion, airway remodeling

Diagnosis:
- Symptoms: Wheezing, dyspnea, chest tightness, cough (worse at night)
- Spirometry: FEV1/FVC ratio <0.70, with ≥12% improvement post-bronchodilator
- Peak flow variability >20%

Stepwise Treatment (GINA Guidelines):
Step 1: As-needed low-dose ICS-formoterol (preferred) or as-needed SABA
Step 2: Low-dose ICS daily OR as-needed ICS-formoterol
Step 3: Low-dose ICS-LABA
Step 4: Medium-dose ICS-LABA
Step 5: High-dose ICS-LABA, add-on therapy (tiotropium, biologics)

Controller Medications:
- Inhaled Corticosteroids (ICS): Most effective anti-inflammatory
- LABA: Always with ICS (never monotherapy)
- LTRA: Montelukast (alternative to ICS)
- Biologics: Omalizumab (anti-IgE), dupilumab (anti-IL4/13), mepolizumab (anti-IL5)

ICS Side Effects:
- Local: Oral candidiasis (thrush), dysphonia
- Prevention: Rinse mouth after use, use spacer with MDI
- Systemic (high doses): Adrenal suppression, osteoporosis, cataracts

Acute Exacerbation:
- SABA nebulizer or MDI with spacer
- Systemic corticosteroids: Prednisone 40-60 mg × 5-7 days
- Ipratropium: Add in severe exacerbation
- Magnesium sulfate IV: Refractory cases

documents.title: Stroke Types and Acute Management
documents.content:
Stroke is sudden onset of focal neurological deficit due to cerebrovascular disease. It is a leading cause of death and disability.

Classification:
1. Ischemic Stroke (87%):
   - Thrombotic: Large vessel atherosclerosis, small vessel (lacunar)
   - Embolic: Cardiac source (AF, valve disease), artery-to-artery
   - Hypoperfusion: Watershed infarcts

2. Hemorrhagic Stroke (13%):
   - Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH): Hypertensive, amyloid angiopathy
   - Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH): Aneurysm rupture, AVM

Acute Evaluation:
- Non-contrast CT head: First-line, rules out hemorrhage
- CTA/MRA: Large vessel occlusion detection
- MRI with DWI: Most sensitive for acute ischemia
- Labs: Glucose, CBC, PT/INR, troponin
- ECG: Atrial fibrillation screening

NIHSS Score: Quantifies stroke severity (0-42 points)

Acute Ischemic Stroke Treatment:
1. IV Alteplase (tPA): Within 4.5 hours of symptom onset
   - Dose: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), 10% bolus, rest over 60 min
   - Contraindications: Recent surgery, ICH, BP >185/110, platelets <100k

2. Mechanical Thrombectomy: Large vessel occlusion
   - Within 24 hours if salvageable tissue on imaging
   - ICA or proximal MCA occlusion

3. Aspirin: Within 24-48 hours (after ruling out ICH)

Hemorrhagic Stroke:
- Reverse anticoagulation (vitamin K, PCC, idarucizumab for dabigatran)
- BP control: Target SBP <140 in ICH
- Neurosurgical evaluation for evacuation
- SAH: Secure aneurysm (coiling or clipping), nimodipine for vasospasm

Secondary Prevention:
- Antiplatelets, statins, BP control
- Anticoagulation for AF (CHA2DS2-VASc score)
- Carotid endarterectomy for symptomatic stenosis >70%

documents.title: Hypertension Diagnosis and Treatment
documents.content:
Hypertension is sustained elevation of blood pressure, a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease, stroke, and kidney disease.

Classification (ACC/AHA 2017):
- Normal: <120/<80 mmHg
- Elevated: 120-129/<80 mmHg
- Stage 1 HTN: 130-139 or 80-89 mmHg
- Stage 2 HTN: ≥140 or ≥90 mmHg
- Hypertensive Crisis: >180/>120 mmHg

Diagnosis:
- Average of ≥2 readings on ≥2 occasions
- Ambulatory BP monitoring (ABPM) confirms diagnosis
- Exclude white coat hypertension

Evaluation:
- Assess end-organ damage: LVH, retinopathy, nephropathy
- Screen for secondary causes if resistant or early-onset
- Cardiovascular risk assessment

Secondary Hypertension Causes:
- Renal artery stenosis, primary aldosteronism
- Pheochromocytoma, Cushing syndrome
- OSA, coarctation of aorta
- Medications: NSAIDs, steroids, OCPs

First-Line Antihypertensives:
1. Thiazide diuretics: Chlorthalidone, HCTZ
2. ACE inhibitors: Lisinopril, enalapril
3. ARBs: Losartan, valsartan
4. Calcium channel blockers: Amlodipine (DHP), diltiazem (non-DHP)

Special Populations:
- Diabetes/CKD: ACEi or ARB preferred (renal protection)
- Heart failure: ACEi/ARB + beta-blocker + diuretic
- Black patients: CCB or thiazide preferred initial therapy
- Pregnancy: Labetalol, methyldopa, nifedipine (avoid ACEi/ARB)

Resistant Hypertension:
- BP above goal despite 3 drugs (including diuretic)
- Add mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (spironolactone)

Hypertensive Emergency:
- BP >180/120 with acute end-organ damage
- IV medications: Nicardipine, labetalol, nitroprusside
- Reduce BP by 25% in first hour

documents.title: Cardiac Arrhythmias Overview
documents.content:
Cardiac arrhythmias are disorders of heart rate or rhythm due to abnormal impulse generation or conduction.

Atrial Fibrillation (Most Common Sustained Arrhythmia):
- Irregularly irregular rhythm, absent P waves
- Risk factors: HTN, heart failure, valve disease, hyperthyroidism
- Complications: Stroke (5x increased risk), heart failure

AF Management:
1. Rate Control: Target HR <110 at rest
   - Beta-blockers (metoprolol), CCB (diltiazem), digoxin
2. Rhythm Control: Consider if symptomatic
   - Cardioversion (electrical or pharmacological)
   - Antiarrhythmics: Amiodarone, flecainide, sotalol
   - Catheter ablation
3. Anticoagulation: Stroke prevention
   - CHA2DS2-VASc score guides therapy
   - DOACs preferred (apixaban, rivaroxaban) or warfarin

Ventricular Arrhythmias:
- Ventricular Tachycardia (VT): Wide complex, rate >100
  - Unstable: Immediate synchronized cardioversion
  - Stable: IV amiodarone or lidocaine
- Ventricular Fibrillation (VF): Medical emergency
  - Defibrillation, CPR, epinephrine
- Torsades de Pointes: Polymorphic VT with QT prolongation
  - Treatment: IV magnesium sulfate, correct electrolytes

Bradyarrhythmias:
- Sinus bradycardia: HR <60, often benign
- Heart blocks: First, second (Mobitz I/II), third degree
- Symptomatic bradycardia: Atropine, transcutaneous pacing
- Permanent pacemaker for: Symptomatic bradycardia, Mobitz II, third-degree block

Supraventricular Tachycardia (SVT):
- Narrow complex, regular, rate 150-250
- Vagal maneuvers: Carotid massage, Valsalva
- Adenosine: 6mg rapid IV push, then 12mg
- If refractory: Beta-blocker, CCB, cardioversion

documents.title: Acute Kidney Injury Classification
documents.content:
Acute kidney injury (AKI) is sudden decline in kidney function measured by rise in serum creatinine or decrease in urine output.

KDIGO Classification:
Stage 1: Cr increase 1.5-1.9x baseline OR ≥0.3 mg/dL increase OR UO <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6-12h
Stage 2: Cr increase 2.0-2.9x baseline OR UO <0.5 mL/kg/h for ≥12h  
Stage 3: Cr increase ≥3.0x baseline OR Cr ≥4.0 mg/dL OR initiation of RRT OR UO <0.3 mL/kg/h for ≥24h or anuria ≥12h

Etiologies:
Pre-renal (55%): Hypovolemia, heart failure, sepsis, hepatorenal syndrome
Intrinsic (40%): ATN (ischemic, nephrotoxic), AIN, glomerulonephritis
Post-renal (5%): BPH, stones, malignancy, neurogenic bladder

Workup: FENa (<1% pre-renal, >2% ATN), urinalysis (muddy brown casts in ATN, WBC casts in AIN/pyelonephritis, RBC casts in GN)

Management: Treat underlying cause, optimize fluid status, avoid nephrotoxins, consider RRT for refractory volume overload, acidosis, hyperkalemia, uremia

documents.title: Chronic Kidney Disease Staging and Management
documents.content:
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is kidney damage or GFR <60 mL/min/1.73m² for ≥3 months.

GFR Staging:
G1: ≥90 (normal or high) - kidney damage with normal GFR
G2: 60-89 (mildly decreased)
G3a: 45-59 (mild-moderate decrease)
G3b: 30-44 (moderate-severe decrease)
G4: 15-29 (severely decreased)
G5: <15 (kidney failure/ESRD)

Albuminuria Categories:
A1: <30 mg/g (normal)
A2: 30-300 mg/g (moderately increased, microalbuminuria)
A3: >300 mg/g (severely increased, macroalbuminuria)

Complications:
- Anemia (decreased erythropoietin)
- Mineral bone disease (hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, secondary hyperparathyroidism)
- Cardiovascular disease
- Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis
- Uremia

Management:
- ACEi/ARB: Slow progression (especially with proteinuria)
- BP control: Target <130/80
- Glycemic control in diabetes
- Phosphate binders, vitamin D analogs
- ESAs for anemia (Hgb target 10-11.5)
- Dietary modifications: Low protein, low potassium, low phosphorus
- RRT preparation: Fistula creation when GFR 15-20

documents.title: Thyroid Disorders Comprehensive Review
documents.content:
Thyroid disorders are common endocrine conditions affecting metabolism, growth, and development.

Hypothyroidism:
- Causes: Hashimoto thyroiditis (most common), iodine deficiency, post-ablation, medications (lithium, amiodarone)
- Symptoms: Fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation, bradycardia, dry skin, myxedema
- Labs: Elevated TSH, low T4/T3; anti-TPO antibodies in Hashimoto
- Treatment: Levothyroxine (starting dose 1.6 mcg/kg, adjust by TSH)

Hyperthyroidism:
- Causes: Graves disease (most common), toxic multinodular goiter, toxic adenoma, thyroiditis
- Symptoms: Weight loss, heat intolerance, tremor, tachycardia/AF, diarrhea, anxiety, exophthalmos (Graves)
- Labs: Low TSH, high T4/T3; TSI positive in Graves
- Treatment: Methimazole (preferred), PTU (pregnancy first trimester), radioactive iodine, surgery
- Thyroid storm: Beta-blockers, PTU, iodine (after PTU), steroids, supportive care

Thyroid Nodules:
- Most common incidental finding
- Evaluate with TSH, ultrasound
- FNA for nodules >1cm or suspicious features
- Bethesda classification guides management

Thyroid Cancer:
- Papillary (80%): Best prognosis, associated with radiation exposure
- Follicular (10%): Good prognosis
- Medullary (5%): From C cells, associated with MEN2, check calcitonin
- Anaplastic: Very aggressive, poor prognosis

documents.title: Adrenal Disorders and Cushing Syndrome
documents.content:
Adrenal disorders involve dysfunction of the adrenal cortex (glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, androgens) or medulla (catecholamines).

Cushing Syndrome (Hypercortisolism):
- Causes: ACTH-dependent (pituitary adenoma=Cushing disease, ectopic ACTH) vs ACTH-independent (adrenal adenoma/carcinoma, exogenous steroids)
- Clinical features: Central obesity, moon facies, buffalo hump, striae, proximal weakness, hypertension, hyperglycemia, osteoporosis, easy bruising
- Diagnosis: 24-hour urine cortisol, late-night salivary cortisol, dexamethasone suppression test
- Localization: ACTH level, high-dose dex suppression, imaging (MRI pituitary, CT adrenals)

Addison Disease (Primary Adrenal Insufficiency):
- Causes: Autoimmune (most common in developed countries), infections (TB, HIV), hemorrhage, metastases
- Symptoms: Fatigue, weight loss, hypotension, hyperpigmentation, salt craving
- Labs: Low cortisol, high ACTH, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
- Diagnosis: ACTH stimulation test (cortisol fails to rise)
- Treatment: Glucocorticoid + mineralocorticoid replacement, stress dosing

Pheochromocytoma:
- Catecholamine-secreting tumor of adrenal medulla
- Classic triad: Episodic headache, sweating, palpitations
- Rule of 10s: 10% bilateral, 10% malignant, 10% extra-adrenal
- Diagnosis: Plasma/urine metanephrines, CT/MRI localization
- Treatment: Alpha-blockade FIRST (phenoxybenzamine), then beta-blockade, then surgical resection

documents.title: Liver Cirrhosis and Complications
documents.content:
Cirrhosis is end-stage liver disease characterized by fibrosis and regenerative nodules, leading to portal hypertension and hepatic dysfunction.

Etiologies:
- Alcohol-related liver disease (most common in West)
- Chronic hepatitis B and C
- NAFLD/NASH (increasing prevalence)
- Autoimmune hepatitis, PBC, PSC
- Hereditary (Wilson disease, hemochromatosis, alpha-1 antitrypsin)

Complications:
1. Portal Hypertension:
   - Varices (esophageal, gastric): Prophylaxis with beta-blockers, band ligation
   - Acute variceal bleeding: Octreotide + antibiotics + endoscopic therapy + TIPS if refractory
   - Ascites: Sodium restriction, diuretics (spironolactone + furosemide), paracentesis
   - Hepatorenal syndrome: Albumin + vasoconstrictors, TIPS, transplant

2. Hepatic Encephalopathy:
   - Precipitants: GI bleed, infection, constipation, medications
   - Treatment: Lactulose (target 2-3 BM/day), rifaximin

3. Hepatocellular Carcinoma:
   - Surveillance: Ultrasound ± AFP every 6 months
   
Child-Pugh Score: Bilirubin, albumin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy (A=5-6, B=7-9, C=10-15)
MELD Score: Predicts 90-day mortality, used for transplant allocation

documents.title: Peptic Ulcer Disease and H. pylori
documents.content:
Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) involves mucosal defects in the stomach or duodenum extending through the muscularis mucosae.

Etiology:
- H. pylori infection (most common cause of duodenal ulcers)
- NSAIDs (most common cause of gastric ulcers)
- Stress ulcers (critically ill patients)
- Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (gastrinoma)
- Less common: Crohn disease, viral infections

Clinical Features:
- Epigastric pain: DU - relieved by food, GU - worsened by food
- Nausea, bloating, early satiety
- Alarm features: Weight loss, anemia, dysphagia, GI bleeding, early satiety

Diagnosis:
- Endoscopy (EGD): Gold standard, allows biopsy
- H. pylori testing: Urea breath test, stool antigen (non-invasive), biopsy urease test

H. pylori Treatment (Triple/Quadruple Therapy):
- PPI + clarithromycin + amoxicillin × 14 days
- Bismuth quadruple: PPI + bismuth + metronidazole + tetracycline × 14 days
- Confirm eradication 4 weeks after treatment completion

Complications:
- GI bleeding: Most common, presents with melena, hematemesis
- Perforation: Acute abdomen, free air on imaging
- Gastric outlet obstruction: Vomiting, succussion splash
- Malignancy: Gastric ulcers have higher risk, biopsy required

documents.title: HIV/AIDS Comprehensive Overview
documents.content:
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) by attacking CD4+ T cells.

Transmission: Sexual contact, blood exposure, vertical (mother to child)

Natural History:
- Acute infection: Flu-like illness 2-4 weeks after exposure
- Clinical latency: Asymptomatic years, CD4 decline
- AIDS: CD4 <200 or AIDS-defining illness

Diagnosis:
- 4th generation HIV Ag/Ab test (preferred screening)
- Confirmatory: HIV-1/HIV-2 differentiation assay
- Viral load (RNA): Confirms acute infection, monitors treatment

AIDS-Defining Conditions:
- Opportunistic infections: PCP, toxoplasmosis, cryptococcosis, CMV, MAC, candidiasis
- Malignancies: Kaposi sarcoma, primary CNS lymphoma, cervical cancer
- Wasting syndrome, HIV encephalopathy

Opportunistic Infection Prophylaxis:
- CD4 <200: TMP-SMX for PCP and toxoplasmosis
- CD4 <100: Azithromycin for MAC
- CD4 <50: Consider CMV screening

Antiretroviral Therapy (ART):
- Start immediately in all patients
- Standard regimen: 2 NRTIs + integrase inhibitor (or NNRTI or boosted PI)
- Goal: Undetectable viral load (<50 copies/mL)
- Resistance testing before starting, at treatment failure

Prevention: PrEP (Truvada/Descovy), condoms, needle exchange, treatment as prevention

documents.title: Tuberculosis Diagnosis and Treatment
documents.content:
Tuberculosis (TB) is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs but can disseminate to any organ.

Risk Factors: HIV (greatest risk), immunosuppression, close contacts, healthcare workers, immigrants from endemic areas, homelessness

Latent TB (LTBI):
- Infected but not infectious
- Positive TST or IGRA, negative CXR, asymptomatic
- Treatment: INH × 9 months, or rifampin × 4 months, or INH/rifapentine weekly × 12 weeks

Active Pulmonary TB:
- Symptoms: Chronic cough, hemoptysis, night sweats, fever, weight loss
- CXR: Upper lobe cavitary lesions, Ghon complex (primary)
- Diagnosis: Sputum AFB smear and culture, nucleic acid amplification test (GeneXpert)

Treatment of Active TB (RIPE):
- Intensive phase (2 months): Rifampin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol
- Continuation phase (4 months): Rifampin + Isoniazid
- Total: 6 months (longer for extrapulmonary/complicated)

Medication Side Effects:
- Rifampin: Orange secretions, hepatotoxicity, drug interactions (P450 inducer)
- Isoniazid: Peripheral neuropathy (give pyridoxine), hepatotoxicity
- Pyrazinamide: Hyperuricemia, hepatotoxicity
- Ethambutol: Optic neuritis (check visual acuity)

Drug-Resistant TB:
- MDR-TB: Resistant to INH and rifampin
- XDR-TB: MDR + fluoroquinolone resistance + second-line injectable resistance
- Requires specialized treatment regimens

documents.title: Anemia Classification and Workup
documents.content:
Anemia is defined as hemoglobin <13 g/dL in men or <12 g/dL in women.

Classification by MCV:
Microcytic (MCV <80):
- Iron deficiency: Most common overall, low ferritin, high TIBC
- Thalassemia: Target cells, normal/elevated ferritin
- Anemia of chronic disease: Low TIBC, normal/elevated ferritin
- Sideroblastic anemia: Ringed sideroblasts on bone marrow

Normocytic (MCV 80-100):
- Acute blood loss
- Hemolysis: Elevated LDH, indirect bilirubin, reticulocytes; decreased haptoglobin
- Anemia of chronic disease
- Bone marrow failure: Aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndrome
- Chronic kidney disease

Macrocytic (MCV >100):
- Megaloblastic: B12 or folate deficiency (hypersegmented neutrophils)
- Non-megaloblastic: Liver disease, hypothyroidism, myelodysplasia
- Reticulocytosis (response to hemolysis or blood loss)

Iron Studies Interpretation:
- Iron deficiency: ↓Iron, ↓Ferritin, ↑TIBC, ↓Transferrin saturation
- Chronic disease: ↓Iron, ↑Ferritin, ↓TIBC, normal/↓Transferrin saturation
- Hemochromatosis: ↑Iron, ↑Ferritin, ↑Transferrin saturation

Hemolytic Workup:
- Coombs test: Positive = autoimmune
- Peripheral smear: Spherocytes, schistocytes, sickle cells
- Hemoglobin electrophoresis for hemoglobinopathies

documents.title: Coagulation Disorders and Anticoagulation
documents.content:
Coagulation disorders involve abnormalities of the clotting cascade, platelets, or both.

Coagulation Cascade:
- Intrinsic pathway: Measured by PTT (XII, XI, IX, VIII)
- Extrinsic pathway: Measured by PT/INR (VII, tissue factor)
- Common pathway: X, V, II (prothrombin), I (fibrinogen)

Inherited Bleeding Disorders:
- Hemophilia A: Factor VIII deficiency, X-linked
- Hemophilia B: Factor IX deficiency, X-linked
- von Willebrand disease: Most common inherited bleeding disorder, quantitative or qualitative vWF defect

Acquired Bleeding:
- Liver disease: Decreased factor synthesis
- Vitamin K deficiency: II, VII, IX, X affected
- DIC: Consumptive coagulopathy, ↑PT/PTT, ↓fibrinogen, ↑D-dimer, schistocytes

Thrombophilias:
- Factor V Leiden (most common inherited)
- Prothrombin gene mutation
- Protein C, Protein S, Antithrombin deficiency
- Antiphospholipid syndrome

Anticoagulation:
- Heparin: Activates antithrombin, monitor with PTT, reverse with protamine
- LMWH (enoxaparin): Factor Xa inhibition, no routine monitoring, partial protamine reversal
- Warfarin: Vitamin K antagonist, monitor with INR, reverse with vitamin K ± PCC/FFP
- DOACs: 
  - Dabigatran: Direct thrombin inhibitor, reverse with idarucizumab
  - Rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban: Factor Xa inhibitors, reverse with andexanet alfa

documents.title: Seizure Classification and Management
documents.content:
Seizures are abnormal, synchronous electrical activity in the brain. Epilepsy is recurrent unprovoked seizures.

Classification:
Focal (partial) seizures:
- Simple partial: No loss of consciousness
- Complex partial: Impaired awareness
- Focal to bilateral tonic-clonic: Starts focal, generalizes

Generalized seizures:
- Absence: Staring spells, 3 Hz spike-wave on EEG
- Tonic-clonic (grand mal): Muscle stiffening then jerking
- Myoclonic: Brief muscle jerks
- Atonic: Sudden loss of muscle tone (drop attacks)

Status Epilepticus: Seizure >5 minutes or recurrent without recovery
- Emergency management: ABCs, benzodiazepines (lorazepam 4mg IV), then fosphenytoin or levetiracetam

Antiepileptic Drug Selection:
- Focal: Carbamazepine, lamotrigine, levetiracetam, oxcarbazepine
- Generalized tonic-clonic: Valproate, lamotrigine, levetiracetam
- Absence: Ethosuximide (first-line), valproate, lamotrigine
- Myoclonic: Valproate, levetiracetam

Medication Side Effects:
- Carbamazepine: Hyponatremia, DRESS, aplastic anemia, HLA-B*1502 testing (Asians)
- Valproate: Weight gain, tremor, hepatotoxicity, teratogenic (neural tube defects)
- Phenytoin: Gingival hyperplasia, hirsutism, osteomalacia, purple glove syndrome
- Lamotrigine: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (slow titration)

Pregnancy: Levetiracetam and lamotrigine preferred; folic acid supplementation

documents.title: Headache Types and Red Flags
documents.content:
Headaches are classified as primary (no underlying cause) or secondary (symptom of another condition).

Primary Headaches:
1. Tension-type: Most common, bilateral pressure/tightness, no nausea/photophobia
   - Treatment: NSAIDs, acetaminophen; prophylaxis with amitriptyline

2. Migraine: Unilateral, pulsating, moderate-severe, nausea/vomiting, photo/phonophobia
   - Aura in 25%: Visual (scotoma, fortification), sensory, motor
   - Acute treatment: NSAIDs, triptans (5-HT1B/1D agonists), antiemetics
   - Prophylaxis (>4 headaches/month): Propranolol, topiramate, amitriptyline, CGRP inhibitors

3. Cluster: Unilateral severe periorbital pain, autonomic symptoms (lacrimation, rhinorrhea, ptosis)
   - Occurs in clusters, male predominance
   - Acute: High-flow oxygen, sumatriptan injection
   - Prophylaxis: Verapamil, prednisone for cluster period

RED FLAGS (SNOOOP):
- Systemic symptoms/illness
- Neurological symptoms
- Onset sudden (thunderclap)
- Older age (>50, new headache)
- Pattern change
- Papilledema

Secondary Headache Causes:
- Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Thunderclap, "worst headache of life"
- Meningitis: Fever, neck stiffness, photophobia
- Temporal arteritis: Age >50, jaw claudication, visual changes, elevated ESR
- Idiopathic intracranial hypertension: Young obese women, papilledema, pulsatile tinnitus
- Brain tumor: Progressive, worse in morning, positional

documents.title: Rheumatoid Arthritis Diagnosis and Treatment
documents.content:
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic, systemic autoimmune disease primarily affecting the joints.

Clinical Features:
- Symmetric polyarthritis: Small joints (MCP, PIP, wrists), spares DIP
- Morning stiffness >1 hour
- Extra-articular: Rheumatoid nodules, pulmonary fibrosis, pericarditis, vasculitis
- Joint deformities: Swan neck, boutonniere, ulnar deviation, Z-thumb

Diagnosis:
- Labs: RF (70% sensitive), anti-CCP (more specific), elevated ESR/CRP
- Imaging: X-ray (juxta-articular osteopenia, erosions, joint space narrowing)
- ACR/EULAR criteria: Joint involvement, serology, acute phase reactants, duration

Treatment Goals: Remission or low disease activity within 6 months

Medications:
DMARDs (Disease-Modifying):
- Conventional: Methotrexate (first-line), hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, leflunomide
- Biologic: TNF inhibitors (adalimumab, etanercept), IL-6 inhibitors (tocilizumab), JAK inhibitors (tofacitinib)

Methotrexate:
- Start 10-15 mg weekly, max 25 mg
- Add folic acid to reduce side effects
- Monitor: CBC, LFTs, renal function
- Side effects: Hepatotoxicity, cytopenias, pneumonitis
- Contraindicated in pregnancy

Prednisone: Bridging therapy while waiting for DMARDs to work

NSAIDs: Symptomatic relief only, do not prevent joint damage

documents.title: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
documents.content:
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a multisystem autoimmune disease with diverse manifestations.

Epidemiology: Female predominance (9:1), African American > Caucasian, reproductive age

Clinical Features (SOAP BRAIN MD):
- Serositis (pleuritis, pericarditis)
- Oral ulcers (painless)
- Arthritis (non-erosive)
- Photosensitivity
- Blood disorders (hemolytic anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia)
- Renal disease (lupus nephritis - major cause of morbidity)
- ANA positive
- Immunologic markers (anti-dsDNA, anti-Smith, anti-phospholipid)
- Neurologic (seizures, psychosis)
- Malar rash, Discoid rash

Diagnostic Criteria: ACR/EULAR 2019 - entry criterion ANA ≥1:80, then weighted criteria

Key Antibodies:
- ANA: Sensitive but not specific (screening)
- Anti-dsDNA: Specific, correlates with disease activity, lupus nephritis
- Anti-Smith: Most specific
- Anti-histone: Drug-induced lupus
- Anti-Ro/La: Neonatal lupus, Sjögren overlap

Lupus Nephritis:
- Class I-VI based on biopsy
- Class III/IV: Proliferative, require immunosuppression
- Treatment: Corticosteroids + mycophenolate or cyclophosphamide

General Treatment:
- Hydroxychloroquine: All patients (reduces flares, mortality)
- NSAIDs: Arthritis, serositis
- Corticosteroids: Flares
- Immunosuppressants: Severe manifestations (azathioprine, mycophenolate, cyclophosphamide)
- Belimumab: FDA-approved biologic for active SLE
